utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, Bernie.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey, how’s my little astronautie hottie?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I guess. It’s just, being cooped up in this tin can for weeks on end is starting to get to me.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, hang in there. You just have a couple more days to go, and then you’ll be home.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I got to get back to work. I love you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Love you too. Hey, Bernie? Before you go, can you do something for me?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What do you want me to do?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, here it is. I really miss gravity. Can you drop something so I can watch it fall?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Really, you’re serious? Okay.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, baby, you’re killing me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ugh. Hey, Sheldon? Hi. This came for you today. It’s from your mom.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, thank you, Penny.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: M-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, wait, here. For your troubles.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, boy, a whole dollar. Now, I can quit my paper route. So, what’s in it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mmm, doesn’t matter. Half the time, he just ends up playing with the box.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s journals and research papers I wrote as a child.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Aw, how cute. Is this like a diary?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, that’s my potty training journal.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really, your potty training journal?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah. And forgive my crude penmanship. I didn’t start typing until I was six.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: August 7, 8:42 a.m. This is humiliating. What was wrong with diapers?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There are some charts in the back where I kept track of shape, colour and consistency.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, disgusting.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, what’s disgusting is he’s still keeping track.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Why do you need all this stuff?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, no, no.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sorry!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I am glad you asked. Are you familiar with the Higgs boson?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Of course, it is, it’s been in the news. And it’s a very famous boson.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nice try. Now, in 1964, Dr. Peter Higgs, accomplished self-promoter and physicist, he wrote a paper postulating the existence of a subatomic particle called the Higgs boson. Now, initially the paper was rejected, but recently, he was proven right, and now he’s on the fast track to win a Nobel prize.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s basically what I said.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, the point is Higgs is being celebrated for work he did 50 years ago, so that got me thinking, perhaps I’ve already hit upon the idea that will win me my Nobel prize.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I didn’t know they gave Nobel prizes for making boom-boom in the potty.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You really think there’s some kind of scientific discovery in here?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, this box only covers my work through nursery school. There’s a good deal more to come. I didn’t really hit my academic stride until I cut out that time-suck known as playing outdoors.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, you’re going to spend hours and hours combing through all this stuff?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s a good point. My time is much too valuable. You know, perhaps I should find someone to do it for me. You know, someone with a rudimentary understanding of science, but whose real talents lie in menial labour.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not gonna happen.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, if I didn’t think you could handle it, I wouldn’t be asking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If you want help, just hire a grad student.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Maybe I could do it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You, really? You can assess the quality of my work? Okay, um, here. I wrote this when I was five years old.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: A proof that algebraic topology can never have a non self-contradictory set of abelion groups. I’m just a blonde monkey to you, aren’t I?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You said it, not me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, Ms. Jenson. Uh, before we begin, may I offer you a refreshment? Water, coffee, tea, a marijuana cigarette?

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: No, thanks. I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, are you sure? Everyone’s smoking them. I think they’re the best.

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: I don’t do drugs.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excellent, yeah. That was a ruse. They’re not the best. Physics is the best. And by the way, coffee was also an unacceptable choice. All right, so I see here you’re from Des Moines, Iowa. Uh, you’re summa cum laude in theoretical physics from Stanford University. Oh, and two years ago, you had a persistent ear infection. I hope that didn’t cause any hearing loss.

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: No, of course not. How did you know about that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I did a comprehensive background check. Medical records, credit reports, criminal history. I trust you paid off those parking tickets.

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: Yes, I did.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hearing unimpaired, good.

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: Look, Dr. Cooper, I really want this position. It would be an incredible honour to work for a man of your brilliance.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Flattery will not get you this job, Ms. Jenson.

utterance.speaker: Ms Jenson
utterance.content: It’s not flattery if it’s the truth.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, well, thank you. Welcome aboard.

utterance.content: You talk to Howard lately?

utterance.content: Uh, yeah, last night. He kept making me drop pencils for him. I got uncomfortable. Hey, Sheldon, hope you’re hungry, they’re serving macaroni and… che-ee-ee-ese.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You’re going to be fine. You survived that Weight Watchers cruise with your mom. And they ran out of low-fat ice cream on day two. Just calm down and take a few deep breaths.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, okay. What am I doing? I’m using up all the oxygen. If I die, promise you’ll never have sex with another man.

utterance.speaker: Raj

utterance.content: Here’s your frozen yoghurt, Dr. Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Alex
utterance.content: Um…

utterance.content: Uh, Alex, a moment. I need a word with Dr. Hofstadter. Do you think it’s appropriate for her to sit with us, given her station?

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Sheldon

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.content: It’s a kindness, Leonard. Otherwise, you’re cruelly tempting them with a glimpse of a world that’s just beyond their soot-stained fingertips.

utterance.speaker: Alex
utterance.content: Oh, okay. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Alex
utterance.content: Is that true? Is he all right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No. But compared to your boss, he’s the poster boy for sanity.

utterance.speaker: Alex
utterance.content: It’s okay, I’ve been around scientists all my life. My dad’s an astronomer at SETI.

utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.content: Really? I don’t know how much you know about primate behaviour, but Sheldon’s assistant was clearly courting Leonard. Were she a mandrill, she would have bent over and displayed her brightly coloured hindquarters like a big red welcome mat. By the way, you try that at the junior prom, you get kicked out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, maybe she was flirting with him, but who cares? Look, I don’t even know where my relationship is with Leonard is right now.

utterance.content: So says your prefrontal cortex. But meanwhile, the limbic system of your brain is calculating that if another woman is attracted to Leonard, it must be because he’s desirable.

utterance.content: Fine, it bothers me a little. No. You know what? This is stupid. It doesn’t bother me. Okay, it bothers me. But only because she wouldn’t stop laughing. Leonard is not that funny.

utterance.content: And there you have it, prefrontal cortex reasoning versus limbic lust. If this were a boxing match, they might call it the thrilla adjacent to the amygdala. If you were a brain scientist, you would be busting a gut right now.

utterance.content: So, how was work today?

utterance.content: Ah, it was all right, I guess. Got to Heimlich a cherry stem out of Sheldon. Caught Raj right in the eye.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh! You’re kidding.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wow. Anything else?

utterance.content: Mmm, the nurse is a woman, so he couldn’t talk to her. She had to bring him a Grover puppet so he could point at what hurt.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, is that it?

utterance.content: I believe Alex may have unearthed the grade school science project that could be my ticket to the Nobel Prize. Behold.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The original title was “A Rederivation of Maxwell’s Equations Regarding Electromagnetism”” I dumbed it down because some of the more religious people in town were starting to say I was a witch.

utterance.speaker: Alex

utterance.speaker: Penny

utterance.content: Oh. Well, you’re lucky. He seems very talented. And I’m sure a lot of people want to work with him.

utterance.content: Hey, Howie, how you feeling?
